explanation:
- OS_FdSet: The function dereferences Set; need the struct definition to see layout and confirm which member is accessed.
- OS_FdSet.object_ids (array size and element type): Critical to determine the number of bytes/elements available and the element type (e.g. uint8_t). This is used to check whether indexing by (local_id >> 3) can go out of bounds and whether the assigned value fits the element type.
- osal_index_t: The local_id arithmetic (shifts, masks, and indexing) depends on the type width and signedness of osal_index_t to determine possible range and behaviour of >> and & operations.
- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex: This call produces local_id and return_code. You must inspect its contract/implementation to know the range of local_id when it returns OS_SUCCESS (i.e. guarantees that local_id is within [0, max-1] or not) and whether it can ever produce values that cause out-of-range indexing.
- OS_GetMaxForObjectType (or equivalent max-stream constant): The valid range for local_id ultimately relates to the maximum number of objects of type OS_STREAM. To prove safety you must compare that maximum to the size of object_ids (typically (max+7)/8).
- OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM: Identifies which object-type maximum is requested; needed to map the object type to the proper max value in OS_GetMaxForObjectType or the OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex logic.
- OS_SUCCESS: The code only writes into object_ids when return_code == OS_SUCCESS. You need the constant to understand the success condition used by OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex.
- OS_CHECK_POINTER: This macro/function is used to validate Set. You must inspect it to ensure it prevents dereferencing a NULL Set (e.g. by returning error or asserting) so that Set->object_ids access is not a potential null-pointer dereference.

These symbols together let the analyzer determine whether the bit-set operation Set->object_ids[local_id >> 3] |= 1 << (local_id & 0x7) can access memory beyond the bounds of object_ids (the concern behind the string.h out-of-bounds MISRA rule), and whether any called helper/macro could hide string.h usage that might cause out-of-bounds accesses.
